Or worse, I've seen this happen:

 

Write code1

Write code2

<realize a r=
efactoring is possible>

Refactor code1/code2 into code3

<happy with the r=
esult, now we write the test>

Write test3

<test3 passes; happy with the r=
esult>

 

This looks like everything is fine, but they didn't realize that=
 their test passed because they wrote it wrong and/or their test doesn't re=
ally cover all the functionality of the code.  These are the risks of writi=
ng the tests after the code.  

 

When people just can't get themselves to=
 write tests first, I tell them to do a little exercise with the code once =
they have written their tests and they are satisfied that they work:  comme=
nt each line of code out one at a time and re-run the tests.  At least one =
test should fail each time and they should also look at the error informati=
on to be sure that the test failed for the expected reason.  It's also good=
 to go the other direction and try to make each test fail one at a time.  A=
 test that has never failed in its existence is a risky test.

 

..David..=
